data.title: Detroit Pistons' Brandon Knight, on Metta World Peace: 'He threw a punch, league should review'
data.meta_description: World Peace, who in 2004 was involved in one of the ugliest incident involving players and fans in NBA history during a game at The Palace of Auburn Hills, denied that he threw at punch at the Pistons' point guard and said he only remembered that Knight was working hard against him defensively immediately before the incident.
data.text:
AUBURN HILLS -- An Artest, by any other name, plays the same.

That was Detroit Pistons guard Brandon Knight's perspective after a scuffle started when Metta World Peace -- the former Ron Artest -- grabbed him around the neck late in the first half of the Los Angeles Lakers' 98-97 win at The Palace of Auburn Hills.

World Peace was assessed a Flagrant-One foul and allowed to remain in the game. Knight insists World Peace threw a punch and should have faced a stiffer penalty after the incident, which occurred with 1:43 remaining in the first half.

"He threw a punch," Knight said. "He held me at first. I was trying to push him off of me. ... That's when he threw a punch. That's when I tried to push him in the face, or whatever it was, whatever I did."

Replays showed that while Knight was defending World Peace away from the ball, the latter threw something akin to a left uppercut while holding Knight around the neck with his right arm. The punch curled and, if landed, did so lightly with the wrist, not the fist.

Even so, a punch usually draws more than a Flagrant-One and Knight said the NBA needs to reconsider the play.

"I was surprised the ref didn't see him throw that punch," Knight said. "The play needs to be reviewed because he definitely threw a punch."

World Peace, who under his former name was a central figure in a notorious Nov. 19, 2004 incident at The Palace of Auburn Hills which altered the way NBA teams handle security -- and which resulted in his league-imposed suspension for the rest of the 2004-05 season -- dismissed Knight's claim.

"If he says that, he says that," World Peace said of the punch accusation. "Whatever. If he says it, whatever."

Asked his version of the incident, World Peace was non-committal.

"I don't really remember," he said. "He was trying his hardest to keep me out of the paint."

After World Peace threw his left, Knight pushed off with his forearm and broke free.

"It felt like he threw a punch," Knight said. "That's why I reacted the way I did."

World Peace's initial decision to grab Knight around the neck seemed to come with no provocation.

"He just grabbed me," Knight said. "I don't know what his reasoning was. I'm not just going to let nobody just grab me and have no response to it. You've got to hold your ground at some point. So I grabbed him and pushed him off of me and that was it.

"The play was over. The whistle had blown and he grabbed me around the neck. If somebody grabs me around the neck, I'm not going to just let that happen."
